This absolutely amazed me. Conan doesn't even eat hot stuff. He doesn't use hot sauce. I do use hot sauce a lot, on a lot of things, but if I dumped one of those super hot ones on anything and then ate it, I would be sincerely scared of what was going to happen, and of getting through it. My throat would be pretty much guaranteed to close up, I would start coughing.  I wouldn't be able to talk much if I wanted to. Conan opened the bottle and dumped it all over the wing, then ate the entire wing, then took a swig straight from the bottle, then sat and thought for a minute and said, "...nah...not gettin' anything.".  HAAAA!  Hilarious.  This was like a feat of strength and daring, combined with a great comedic performance.   He cashed the huge check that he wrote at the beginning of the show. This was big time.

I really hope it doesn't become the norm for guests to come on and do planned bits or go out of their way to try to be entertaining. The doctor thing was funny, but I personally watch this show to get to see actors take off their 'performer' hat and just talk about topics that interest them, have authentic banter and genuine reactions to the spice. The structure of the show allows that to unfold pretty organically- if the guest is willing to participate. I get that Conan's a comedian so he was trying to deliver, but plenty of other comedians have been on the show and been perfectly entertaining by just being themselves and letting the interview become a collaborative effort- not a one man show

I had an epiphany a few years ago. Growing up, everyone speculated what would be created and broadcast if people were given free rein and the technology to be stars in their own little shows. Everyone thought it would be perverted and degenerate content. Turns out, it would be WITTY AND FUNNY. Every other thing on social media is FUNNY. some people share their skills, some share their hobbies, BUT IT IS  wits and humor that rises to the top. We humans literally spend hours recording ourselves doing the silliest things, spend hours editing the recording and put it out there ALL TO MAKE STRANGERS LAUGH. go figure.

Worst episode to date. Too bad it's the season finale. The first half is interesting and entertaining. I loved how Conan gives Sean a compliment for being a good and well-prepared interviewer. I totally agree. Sean is amazing at digging up little-known details and turning them into really interesting questions. But then, after 13:30, Conan transforms into a loud annoying attention-seeking child. Nothing close to actual humor about it. Just a clown. Some people say 'Wow, Conan took over the entire show'. By screaming and acting like a 14 year old? Is that taking over the show? I would just classify it as disrespectful.   But hey, people here seem to love it so it's ok. This is why there's so many flavors of ice cream...opinions and tastes vary. Conan is obviously funny - and I of course laughed at times - but I just felt he was doing a bit the whole time.  He was trying too hard and was so committed to the bit, that I didn't feel that the underlying goal of the show was realized - to disrupt the packaged/manufactured Hollywood interview personae and get a sense of the underlying individual. Conan was so focused on what he was going to say, he often didn't listen or allow Sean to complete his questions.  This episode had its moments, but not a favorite.

I feel this episode perfectly epitomises the difference between American and British humour. All of the comments from Americans are spouting what a comedic masterclass this was, whereas I found it cringey and contrived.   I guess this is why American late night talk shows, SNL etc. have never been popular in the UK. This was so scripted and rehearsed, whereas British humour is more ad hoc and impromptu.

"Read widely". That's just genius! I'm a huge fan of British comedians, and they tend to come off as well educated. Maybe they just fool me because of the accents and vocabulary I'm not familiar with sometimes, but they genuinely seem well educated. That said, American and Canadian comedians are also just great thinkers! You have to be in order to subvert expectations to make us laugh! He was brilliant, even if his style was very blunt. I'm positive that the guy was way smarter than anyone gave him credit for, aside from the people who knew him closely.

He stomped all over the format and denigrated the entire premise, and then turned around and said he hated it when guests say that a show isn't going well.  And maybe that's just part of the joke, but intentionally being a hypocrite isn't automatically funny.  I do appreciate him saying that he had a lot of respect for Sean, and clearly he meant it, but like...if you respect someone, don't steal their show from them.  I guess I'm glad people liked it, but this is way outside of what I've come to enjoy about this show.

Was he trying to off himself? The only thing I can compare this to is a blog that I used to read years ago about someone who consumed a whole bottle of hot sauce every day and wrote about it. He would douse his food with it and drink whatever was left. For changes of pace he would go into a restaurant and challenge the chef to make something so hot that he couldn't finish it. I believe he had kept his blog up somewhere between 100 and 200 days when his entries stopped. No explanation and no one knew what had happened to him. Many of his followers assumed he came to a bad end. I believe the blog was called The Smoking Tongue. I just looked it up and it's been removed. I hope Conan fared well in the suceeding days.

I gotta say, Conan was a pretty sustainable watch for me, even tho his show suffered from the same viewer fatigue that all staged and scripted late night esc shows have.   He just always seemed so willing to go off script. There were a couple times that I realized the show was scripted, because I could see the change from Conan ACTUALLY catching his guests off guard and making them laugh really hard. And vice versa. Bill Burr is one of his best guests for this reason, like I know Bill will shoe horn in some of his act cause hes promoting himself, but its once Conan rebutles that they start to go off script and laugh the hardest.   He seemed more weighed down by the medium I guess. Certainly not as insufferable as Jimmy Fallon or the others. Its nice to see him do other stuff, cause it just affirms that he has that same energy wherever he is. Harder to laugh than some, can easily make others laugh, rewards people with his genuine laugh for things that are objectively funny. Not quick to offend but clearly cant help but find offensive things funny. Hes all-round one of my favorite talk show hosts

I was wondering why Conan is so popular in Finland and I think I figured it out : before he makes fun of anyone he makes fun of himself. That allows him to make fun of everyone else. That is The Finnish Mentality: You want something to be done? Don't throw anyone in there but volunteer yourself if you think it is necessary. Want to have laugh at someone? Start with laughing to your welfare and when you laugh to others they see you are not mean, but guy who finds world funny, and maybe is funny and ridicoulous himself.

"This is not a bit! This is your show! Don't say this is a bit!" is extremely good advice for anyone getting into entertainment right now. Podcasters, interviewers, comedians. Acknowledging a bit is a bit is a very fast way to tank the humor. Looking outside the comedy too much or too soon makes people feel self aware in an uncomfortable way. The same way he brings up "When the guest says 'you're not getting a good show', I see 200 souls leave 200 bodies". Don't tell people what they should or shouldn't be laughing at. Don't tell people where they are. Don't make them aware that you're trying so hard to be funny. Just be funny. Conan didn't yell and scream with a mouthful of milk and beg you to laugh, he expected you to.
CONAAAANNN!!! The Barbarian. Killing it always, awesome episode!!!

Sure hes funny, and ya he likes to control a bit ... but at the end of the day, the guy has no heat taste receptors.  Zero.  Thats the physical bit on our tongue that says 'thats spicey' called TRPV1 receptors.  They react to the capsaicin in peppers.  Some people have a lot of receptors and cant take heat at all, some have only a few of these receptors and enjoy heat ... like Sean.  Yes, it is a situation that can be conditioned, like little kids in Central and South American who chew peppers for lunch ... but if not conditioned, its a physical reaction to bio-parts.  Its hot or its not.  Its not a behavioural choice, its literally in the tastebuds.  Then there's Conan.  This shouldn't exist.  Even after he pours a puddle of Last Dabs 2 million scoville on that wing, he is still in conversational control, he is not in the slightest overwhelmed. Even people with a healthy capability to handle the heat has to gasp for breath and has a little trouble focusing on the question.  Not Conan.  The reaction was all for show.  He has zero TRPV1 receptors.  Look carefully at his face while he is acting out ... and you realize its just acting.  Hes fine, even normal for pictures after.  This is a thing, he should be studied.
performance of a lifetime

I don't like his politics, but Conan is still one of the best at comedy. His commitment to his craft is rarely paralleled by anyone and he seems to honestly just want to make people laugh no matter what it takes. I met him once, and in person he's a nice fella. Was very gracious and in no way arrogant or anything like a lot of celebs I've met (looking at you Ben Affleck). The chicken wings in the pocket, the fake doctor, the guzzling hot sauce and drooling all over the place are exactly the kinds of things you expect from him. And you know he was in severe pain the entire time, but he still pushed it over the top anyways. You have to admire that.

They toured mainland Mexico for almost a year in the sixties, and they were good cooks that picked up lots of tips. Agreed with the comments saying this was a comedic masterclass. It was also a masterclass in how to be a guest on a show. Be prepared. Be interesting. Be memorable. So many celebrities are jaded and bored and make sure they will not be invited back.  Sean Evans will never forget this episode, and with almost 4 million views in under 3 days, Conan has brought a huge amount of exposure to Hot Ones. The money coming in from the views alone has got to be a real boon to the show. But more impressively, Conan balanced his wacky antics with being a good guest, answering questions honestly and paying heartfelt compliments to Sean and crew.  To all those who say Conan is a psychopath, you just don't get it.

Conan is reacting the way he is because there is no reason that this format of show would be popular other than the format that it exists on. Subscription based, or not with adds included creates a format for the youth to be influenced in anyway your algorithm sees fit. Where as in his era, everyone was being influenced by big advertisement to choose certain products and avenues of living. Very important to think about folks. The secret antidote to Capsaicin that nobody knows about is Vegetable or Olive Oil. Its not technically an antidote but it gives the same result. Capsaicin is lipophilic and its attracted to oil, the oil will pull the Capsaicin out of your skin. Then wash the oil off with dish detergent liquid because its specifically designed to cut through oil. The effect is almost instantaneous.

This was amazing. Best Hot Ones ever?  A lot of that is because it was tremendously clever. The humor in Hot Ones is usually from people reacting to the spice. Conan took it the other direction. First, he set everything up for people to expect an amped up version of the usual Hot Ones formula. He brought up bland Irish food, brought his "doctor," etc. The expectation is that he's going to be flipping out over the spice level. But then he flipped it: the heat didn't get to him. And he committed to that and kept going, even when his face was getting flushed and he must have been on fire inside. And during it all, he's having an interesting conversation, with occasional breaks for zaniness later on.
This is why Conan is still the best. Went all in without even thinking. Sean was completely baffled and getting worried but went with it...  By far the Best episode. no question.

BEST EPISODE!!!! LOVE CONAN!!
Back when Conan was getting the short end of the stick from Leno retiring and NBC giving him that time slot to a year later, Leno coming back and them telling Conan to kick rocks, I think every fan of the late night talk shows felt for Conan and knew he had every right to be bitter, and angry about the whole situation. What did he do though? He performed every episode like the showman that he is and for the last show he would ever do for them, he looked right into the camera while trying not to get choked up and genuinely thanked all of the people at NBC that worked with him and gave him his shot to be somebody over the 25-30 years he was there. He then took a second and looked right into the cameras while getting a little teary eyed and told all of his fans and audience how absolutely blessed and thankful he is for each and every one of their support and that he would never forget it. He also said that they should never be cynical because nothing good ever comes from it and as long as you work hard and stay true, good things will happen. I have never forgotten that moment because not only did he have every right to be at least a little cynical, I think it was kind of expected and he still chose to take the high road. And now he's on Hot Ones absolutely killing it, just like he has done with everything for the last 40+ years. Bravo Conan!
lol Conan is the best guest that's been on the show in years! This was hilarious ğŸ˜‚

Hahaha I'm so happy how the first destination Conan brings up is Finland (since I'm from there, obviously). As a place where there's a comedy vacuum, nothing there. People in Finland still love Conan. He started by being hilarious and somehow he turned it into a really wholesome and deep commentary. The music and questions definitely helped, gotta give credit to that. But he was still smoothly transitioning back to humour from serious talk. He seems to be really good at that, going back and forth but not being abrupt. Like he said "to keep up the rhythm".  It's so fascinating how youtube and podcast trend actually brought Conan the same opportunity others whose content couldn't be short format found in there. Like people who couldn't get in-depth discussion on difficult matters or science compressed to some minutes, who needed 30 minutes, an hour, 3 hours. And now Conan can have actual discussions with people.  And Conan truly fooled us again. Watching this I think I know why Conan became the thing he is. He just gives it all and doesn't stop to doubt.
